Award.AwardTitle: Functional Analyses of SR1, A Calcium/Calmodulin-Regulated Transcription Factor, and VOZs, Vascular Plant One Zinc Finger Proteins, In Plant Immunity

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit:
Stressors such as plant pathogens (bacteria, fungi and viruses) cause enormous losses of food crops. Understanding the mechanisms by which plants respond to such stressors and develop immunity is critical to reducing such losses. Calcium, a key signaling molecule in all eukaryotes, has been implicated in plant immunity for decades, and numerous studies have revealed rapid and temporary changes in cellular calcium levels in response to pathogen attacks. However, how calcium regulates pathways involved in plant immunity is poorly understood. This project concerns a small family of transcription factors that are regulated by calcium; these factors were first discovered in plants and then in animals. One of these factors, named SR1, is a negative regulator of plant immunity. SR1 interacts with two other transcription factors. The goal of this project is to use genetic, cell biological, biochemical, molecular, and bioinformatics tools to study the biological roles of SR1-interacting proteins in plant immunity. Single and double mutants of SR1-interacting transcription factors will be used to analyze plant defense responses, the roles and functional significance of various conserved domains in SR1 will be studied, and global identification of targets of SR1 and its interacting transcription factors will be implemented. Overall, this project will contribute to understanding the functions of a calcium-regulated transcription factor in plant immunity.

Broader Impacts:
The knowledge obtained from this project will be relevant to agriculturally important plants as the calcium-modulated transcription factors are highly conserved in crop plants; a better understanding of the function of SR1 and its interacting proteins will have potential applications in reducing the food crop spoilage that results from infection with plant pathogens. This project will integrate research and teaching by training high school students, undergraduate students, a graduate student and a postdoctoral researcher in various aspects of genetics, bioinformatics, cell and molecular biology and by encouraging their participation in national scientific meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plants are constantly exposed to many different biotic (e.g. pathogens and insects) and abiotic stresses (e g. drought, cold and heat) in their environment.  These stresses are the major limiting factors of crop yields.  The understanding of the mechanisms by which plants respond to various stresses is necessary to develop plant varieties that can grow under adverse environmental conditions. To cope with stresses plants reprogram their gene expression.  However, little is known about the genes that confer tolerance or sensitivity to various stresses. The focus of this proposal was to investigate the roles and the mechanisms of action of three proteins called stress-responsive1 (SR1) and vascular one-zinc finger (VOZ) transcription factors in biotic and abiotic stresses. Mutant plants that do not express either SR1 or VOZs show altered stress responses. By performing genome-wide expression analysis in wild-type, mutant and complemented lines of SR1 and VOZ transcription factors we have identified global targets of these transcription factors.  SR1 transcription factor regulates the expression of about 3000 genes and about 60% appear to be the direct targets of this transcription factor whereas VOZs regulate the expression of about 100 genes.  Binding of SR1 to promoters of several SR1-regulated genes was confirmed by chromatin immunoprecipitation studies.  Furthermore, our studies have revealed novel roles for these transcription factors in different stresses.  Depending on the stress, these transcription factors act either as a positive or a negative regulator of stress tolerance.   Overall, this work has provided novel insights into the functions of three transcription factors in stress responses. Furthermore, our studies have revealed that SR1 is an important regulator of multiple stress responses in plants. This project has allowed us to train one graduate student and four postdoctoral research associates (two women and two men) in molecular genetics, genomics, and bioinformatics.  Four female undergraduate students including one student from Minnesota (NSF-REU summer intern) were trained in basic molecular genetic tools and in characterizing mutant plants.
